ranked_diseases.explanation: Strong match with status epilepticus, myoclonus, global developmental delay, and hypotonia. Dravet syndrome typically presents in infancy with seizures progressing to status epilepticus and myoclonic seizures, along with developmental regression.
Features multiple seizure types including myoclonic seizures, developmental delay, and hypotonia. The reference cases show similar patterns with various seizure types and developmental issues.
Characterized by myoclonic seizures, developmental delay, and hypotonia. The age of onset and seizure pattern are consistent with this diagnosis.
Presents with early-onset epilepsy, myoclonus, severe developmental delay, hypotonia, and nystagmus. All features match the patient's presentation.
Features early-onset seizures, myoclonus, severe developmental delay, hypotonia, and visual abnormalities including nystagmus. More common in females.
Can present with early-onset epilepsy including status epilepticus, developmental delay, hypotonia, and movement disorders. Variable phenotype matches patient presentation.
Features developmental delay, speech impairment, hypotonia, seizures including myoclonic, and characteristic movement abnormalities. Nystagmus can occur.
Early-onset epilepsy with status epilepticus, myoclonus, severe developmental delay, and hypotonia are characteristic features.
